text: Yeah, it's more the latter. It's more how they're weighted. The portfolio that you described, and you're absolutely right, the major holdings in a portfolio like that don't change all that much. Now, the weightings will change a little bit, again, based on valuations, because we still have a valuation impact in everything that we do. So the weights will change, but by and large, the portfolio is what it is. So what we're looking at is our belief in the need for that particular regime over the coming whatever time period we're talking about, a horizon. So our signals to weight those portfolios, and you can think about, we just think about the business cycle. So the business cycle in correction periods or bear markets, deflationary periods like we're in right now, the risk of inflation over the short term, over the coming quarter or so, is pretty low. Prices are falling, commodity prices are falling, oil has rebounded a little bit from its lows, but by and large, what we're seeing is broadly deflationary. And we could have an argument over, does the BLS correctly measure inflation and all of those things. But putting all that aside, an inflation type portfolio is not something that we need to be as concerned with, again, over the coming quarter as maybe we normally do. So we'll look at and weighting these different portfolios to downweight that. So that's what we're looking at. And then we'll look at what we're looking at over the next couple of months. So what we're looking at is what we've done over the last couple of months.
